language_info.description: Complete beginner level focusing on survival Dutch

content.text: Welkom! In this lesson, you'll learn how to meet and greet people in Dutch. Let's go to the park!

content.title: Subject Pronoun: ik
content.explanation: To talk about yourself, you use the pronoun 'ik', which means 'I'.

content.title: The Verb 'heten'
content.explanation: 'Heten' means 'to be called'. When you talk about yourself, you say 'ik heet...'

content.title: Subject Pronoun: jij / je
content.explanation: 'Jij' is the Dutch word for 'you' (informal). You can often use the shorter form 'je'.

content.title: The Verb 'zijn'
content.explanation: 'Zijn' means 'to be'. To say 'I am', you use 'Ik ben...'

data.tip: This sounds very similar to the English name 'Ben'.

content.title: WH- Questions
content.explanation: Questions with words like 'Waar' (Where) or 'Wie' (Who) usually follow this structure: Question Word + Verb + Subject.

data.tip: The 'g' sound is a soft, throaty sound, typical in Dutch.

content.title: A Friendly Hello
content.setting: You are in the park and someone greets you. Let's practice introducing yourselves.

user_goal.title: Tell her your name.
user_goal.prompt: Ik heet Eva. Hoe heet jij?

extract_info.user_name: Extract the user's name from their message.

content.text: Great job! Now, let's learn about politeness. Dutch has formal and informal ways of saying 'you'.

content.title: Formal 'You': u
content.explanation: Use 'u' when speaking to someone you don't know, someone older, or in a formal setting. It's a sign of respect.

content.title: Verbs with 'u'
content.explanation: When using 'u', the verbs change. For example: 'u bent' (you are) and 'u heet' (you are called).

content.title: The Verb 'komen'
content.explanation: 'Komen' means 'to come'. To say where you come from, you say 'Ik kom uit...'

content.title: Verb-Second Word Order
content.explanation: In simple Dutch sentences, the verb is almost always the second element. For example: 'Ik (1) kom (2) uit Nederland.'

content.title: Subject Pronouns: hij & zij/ze
content.explanation: To talk about other people, use 'hij' (he) and 'zij' or 'ze' (she).

content.title: Verbs with 'hij' and 'zij'
content.explanation: For 'hij' and 'zij', the verb form is usually the stem + t. Example: 'hij komt', 'zij heet', 'hij is'.

content.title: Yes/No Questions
content.explanation: To ask a yes/no question, you start the sentence with the verb. The word order is: Verb + Subject + ...?

content.title: Plural Pronouns
content.explanation: Let's learn the plural pronouns: 'wij/we' (we), 'jullie' (you all), and 'zij/ze' (they).

content.text: Let's put everything together! You are now ready to have a short conversation with someone new.

content.title: Making a new friend
content.setting: You're enjoying the day in a Dutch park. Someone sits next to you and starts a conversation. Use everything you've learned!

user_goal.title: Greet him back and introduce yourself.

extract_info.user_name: Extract the user's name from their message.

user_goal.title: Say where you're from and then ask him where he is from.
user_goal.prompt: Aangenaam, {user_name}. Ik heet Lars. Waar kom je vandaan?

extract_info.user_country: Extract the user's country from their message.

user_goal.title: Answer 'yes'.
user_goal.prompt: Ik kom uit Nederland. Leuk dat je uit {user_country} komt! Spreek je Engels?

content.text: Welkom terug! Let's learn to talk about your home, family, and share contact information. We'll start with how to talk about your things.

content.title: Articles: 'De' and 'Het'
content.explanation: Remember 'de' and 'het' both mean 'the'. It's important to learn the article with the noun, as it affects other grammar points.

content.title: Possessive Adjective: mijn
content.explanation: 'Mijn' means 'my' and can be used for both 'de' and 'het' words. For example: 'mijn huis'.

data.tip: The 'ui' sound is unique. It's like saying 'ow' in 'how', but with more rounded lips.

content.text: You can use 'Ik heb...' to talk about your family. For example: 'Ik heb een moeder.'

content.title: Possessive Adjective: jouw
content.explanation: 'Jouw' means 'your' (informal). For example: 'jouw moeder'.

content.title: Possessives: zijn & haar
content.explanation: 'Zijn' means 'his' and 'haar' means 'her'. For example: 'zijn broer', 'haar huis'.

data.tip: The 'r' is a rolling 'r' sound, common in Dutch.

content.title: Showing Family Photos
content.setting: You are at your new Dutch friend's house, and they are showing you a family photo.

user_goal.title: Say you have a brother.
user_goal.prompt: Kijk, dit is mijn moeder. Heb jij een broer?

extract_info.brother_name: Extract the brother's name from the user's message.

user_goal.title: Say 'His house is nice.'
user_goal.prompt: Ah, {brother_name}. Dat is een mooie naam.

content.text: Goed gedaan! Now let's learn how to ask and answer questions about age. For that, we need numbers!

content.title: Numbers 0-10
content.explanation: 0-nul, 1-een, 2-twee, 3-drie, 4-vier, 5-vijf, 6-zes, 7-zeven, 8-acht, 9-negen, 10-tien.

content.title: Numbers 11-20
content.explanation: 11-elf, 12-twaalf, 13-dertien, 14-veertien, 15-vijftien, 16-zestien, 17-zeventien, 18-achttien, 19-negentien, 20-twintig.

content.text: To answer 'Hoe oud ben je?', you can say: 'Ik ben [number] jaar oud.' or simply 'Ik ben [number].'

content.title: Numbers 20-100
content.explanation: Tens: 20-twintig, 30-dertig, 40-veertig, 50-vijftig, 60-zestig, 70-zeventig, 80-tachtig, 90-negentig, 100-honderd.

content.text: For numbers like 21, you say 'een-en-twintig' (one-and-twenty). This pattern continues for other numbers.

content.title: Possessive Adjective: uw
content.explanation: Use 'uw' for the formal 'your'. Example: 'Wat is uw adres?'

content.title: Plurals: adding -s or -en
content.explanation: A common way to make nouns plural is to add -s (tafel -> tafels) or -en (stoel -> stoelen). We'll explore more rules later.

content.title: Plural Possessives: ons/onze, jullie, hun
content.explanation: 'ons/onze' (our), 'jullie' (your, plural), 'hun' (their). Use 'ons' for 'het'-words (ons huis) and 'onze' for 'de'-words (onze tafel).

content.text: Let's put it all together! You're ready to exchange personal information with a new acquaintance.

content.title: Exchanging Contact Info
content.setting: You're signing up for a library card and the librarian is asking for your details. Use formal language.

user_goal.prompt: Goedemiddag. Ik help u graag. Hoe oud bent u?
